Title: What is this??
Content:
After many years of having a blog under my name, Iâ€™ve decided to go anonymous for this one. The reason for this is mainly I just want someplace I donâ€™t have to censor myself. In my other blogs, I always said that I would write what I wanted but then something very personal would come to mind and Iâ€™d think about friends and family reading it and never write it, and eventually, the blog would go stale and Iâ€™d stop altogether. Hopefully, with this one, I can find the freedom to write what I want to.
In that vein, I was recently diagnosed with Type II Diabetes.Â  It wasnâ€™t really a surprise to get that diagnosis given the amount of junk I ate with no exercise. Iâ€™ve tried over the years to get my health under control and would do well for a few weeks, maybe a few months but Iâ€™d always slide back into the old habits. This time is different. I hate to be that cliche but the consequences of diabetes are dire and very, very scary to me. Itâ€™s been almost a month since my diagnosis and since then Iâ€™ve stopped eating fast food, junk food, candy bars, and most sugar and all soft drinks. This was done cold turkey and while the first week or so was pretty bad with cravings and headaches Iâ€™ve settled nicely into a routine of buying and cooking healthy foods like fish, turkey, chicken, lots of veggies, hummus, and other diabetic-friendly foods. My insurance company sent me a glucose monitor which arrived after that first week and Iâ€™m happy to say that every time Iâ€™ve checked my glucose it has been within the normal range of <140 two hours after eating and <99 fasting. In the span of a month, Iâ€™ve gone from someone who almost cried at the thought of having to do one finger stick a day to someone who has to stop themself from multiple sticks a day just for the data points. I have been checking after some meals just to get an idea of a baseline for me and so far, so good.
Something else Iâ€™ve been doing is regular exercise. I know the benefits of regular exercise but it seems like in my process of starting and stopping I just forget how much better I feel. My mind is clearer, I have more energy and my blood pressure, which was also high at my last Drâ€™s visit, has been within a normal range since I started tracking it. Having a way to monitor my progress via glucose and bp checks is very motivating to me. I am fully aware of the line between â€œgood data pointsâ€ and obsessing over it and Iâ€™m very aware of not crossing that line.
I think this blog is going to be very good for me as this post has just flowed out of me. Iâ€™ve only told a few people about my diabetes diagnosis since itâ€™s something I feel like is completely self-inflicted but I think this will give me a great outlet to just get whatâ€™s rattling around inside my head out.

Title: Iâ€™m An Apple Now
Content:
Iâ€™m typing this entry from my shiny, new Apple iPad Pro with the new M1 processor. Recently I was doing some research for a family member about moving from an Android phone to an iPhone. That research prompted me, an Android user for the past 12 years, to get an iPhone 12 Pro. To say that I am impressed by the ease of use, quality and overall Apple friendly world is an understatement. Itâ€™s been a really long time since I was excited about technology. In my Android days Iâ€™ve rooted phones, installed custom ROMs, sideloaded various apps I didnâ€™t really need and even put together a few basic apps that never really took off. The latest releases of Android and the Google Pixel hardware left me underwhelmed for the last several years.
Everything in Android land just seems to lag behind whatâ€™s available for the Apple world and when Android does get a similar feature itâ€™s buggy and can be a real pita to deal with. I donâ€™t fault the Android devs for this, no, I fault the wide base of phones/manufacturers that Android runs on. Every hardware platform and revision has quirks that must be accounted for in the Android OS. Apple, on the other hand, doesnâ€™t have to deal with this since their software runs on hardware they have ultimate control over.
Thatâ€™s not to say I think Android is junk I just think given my experience with it I wanted a change and changes I have made. Since I got my iPhone ~2 weeks ago I have purchased AirPod Pros and the new iPad Pro that I am writing this post with. Iâ€™m also using the Logitech Combo Touch case for the iPad and I must say the keyboard functionality is amazing. So much so that I havenâ€™t really used my laptop since getting it. I am also completely enamored with the AirPod Pros! I have been looking for a truly wireless earphones for years and every pair Iâ€™ve tried with an Android phone has just sucked. Random disconnects/skips while the phone is in my pocket and an overall crappy sound. The AirPods are completely different and the noise cancelling tech in them truly amazes me. I have a pair of Bose Quiet Comfort headphones and while I use them frequently the noise cancelling always gives me a feeling of pressure in my ears and head. The AirPods have a vent that allows air/sound to exit and it makes the noise cancelling so much more useful to me. Also, there is a â€œtransparencyâ€ mode which is basically using the external mics to pass sound through. It works so well that I actually hear somethings better with the AirPods in and in transparency mode than I do without them.
So, there you have it. I am officially an Apple now and Iâ€™m pretty OK with that.

Title: A Walk A Day?
Content:
As I mentioned previously I was diagnosed as a type II diabetic at the beginning of May 2021. It really threw my world into turmoil. The same day I was diagnosed I also found out I got a job that I had applied for at my current company. Talk about an overwhelming day! I know many, many people live with type II diabetes and survive but I didnâ€™t want to be one of them. I didnâ€™t want to have to worry about what I ate or check my blood sugar simply because I felt like it made me feel old. For the first time in my life I feel like an old person and I donâ€™t want to. I know that may sound stupid or maybe even conceited but Iâ€™ve seen up close what getting old is like and to be quite honest Iâ€™m not sure if want any part of it.
The day after I was diagnosed I went for a walk with my dog. More than just a stroll around the yard, he and I went around a neighborhood loop that I used to do quite regularly. It felt really good and it was the first time Iâ€™d taken him on that loop since I got him. I felt kinda bad for that. He gets plenty of exercise during the week but itâ€™s not with me. Since then weâ€™ve done that loop, and different loop, at least once a day but usually twice a day. Walking makes me feel good and walking with my dog makes me feel even better. Yes, I consider myself a pet parent and yes my dog is my best friend. Iâ€™m ok with that and when I got him I had planned on being â€œthat guyâ€ who takes his dog everywhere that heâ€™s allowed. I havenâ€™t done that. Heâ€™s got a bit of a barking issue when weâ€™re out and about and he sees other people. Itâ€™s totally my fault and my failure to acclimate him to that environment. But, anyway, thatâ€™s not what this post is about.
Iâ€™ve been walking at least twice a day now for almost a month and Iâ€™ve expanded out from my neighborhood to a park thatâ€™s close-ish to my house. My plan with the new role is to do a walk every morning at this park and then go back home and get ready for my work day. The new role will allow me to have a better work/life balance and at this point I have to prioritize my health over everything else. I donâ€™t want to end up on insulin or lose a limb due to my lack of discipline. (SideNote: I know that a lot of diabetics are unable to manage their conditions with just diet and exercise but at this point in my journey it looks like I will be able to do that so when I say things about discipline just know that I am only referring to myself.) If Iâ€™ve learned anything in the corporate world itâ€™s that â€œThe Companyâ€ doesnâ€™t give a shit about you, and you can be replaced. So from here on out my health, both physical and mental, come first. If that means finding a new job at a different company then so be it.
This post was kind of all over the place but whatever. What it boils down to is my health and well being trump any company that I will ever work for. I see and understand that now and I will do what I need to do to fix my health and make my life better.

Title: The Worst, but Ok

In the last month Iâ€™ve taken over 3000 pictures! Iâ€™m amazed by that and itâ€™s because Iâ€™ve made it part of my day. It doesnâ€™t happen with every picture, obviously, so Iâ€™ve had some very â€œhappy accidentsâ€ with pics Iâ€™ve taken but itâ€™s fueling a fire inside of me to keep pushing myself to do the 15-20 minutes a day to capture those moments. This leads me into a discussion Iâ€m having with myself about selling prints of my pictures. I landed in my current field b/c I was always â€œgood with computersâ€ and computers used to be a hobby for me but when I started doing it every day I quickly got fed up and now Iâ€™m a burned out husk who literally dreads every single day I have to do the jobâ€¦Ok, maybe thatâ€™s a bit dramaticâ€¦lolâ€¦but Iâ€™m worried if I start thinking about monetizing photography Iâ€™ll end up the same way towards it. My tentative plan is to order some prints for myself and see how they look. Iâ€™m under no illusion about becoming a full time photographer and actually paying my bills. I have thought about checking out real estate photography. A good wide angle lens for my dslr and I think I could get some work that wouldnâ€™t require me to actually deal with that many peopleâ€¦It would be awesome for this hobby to pay for, or at least contribute to, the costs of it. Good glass isnâ€™t cheap and Iâ€™m firmly in the camp of buy a cheaper camera and dump that money into lenses. With a little bit of planning lenses can be future proofed so thereâ€™s room to grow into them.
I typed that whole paragraph and didnâ€™t really get to the point I wanted to make. Someone I really look up to and follow on twitter posted something a few days ago that really struck a chord. â€œWhy not me?â€ Itâ€™s such a simple phrase but itâ€™s a life changing way of think, to me at least. Iâ€™m not saying I want to be a famous photographer butâ€¦why not me? Iâ€™m putting in the work, Iâ€™m challenging myself and Iâ€™m learning more and more every day. Iâ€™ve dabbled in photography for over a decade now and even when I wasnâ€™t actively taking pictures I was reading photography blogs, finding photographers I liked and studying their work. I post the type of pictures *I* like and the type of edits that *I* like. If other people like them, great! If not, thatâ€™s cool too. The key to this is mindset and consistency. I mentioned earlier Iâ€™ve taken over 3000 pics and out of those Iâ€™ve put in the â€œto be processedâ€ folder ~50. OUt of that 50 Iâ€™ve editing ~30 and posted ~20. Iâ€™m keeping every pic I take and Iâ€™m shouting in raw and Iâ€™m regularly going back through to see if anything stands out after a few days/weeks of sitting on my hard drive. Iâ€™ve found a few that have given me butterflies in my stomach after going back to them.
Ok, well, I didnâ€™t expect this entry to be this long but itâ€™s definitely helped to get the thoughts rattling around my head out in a structured form. Today Iâ€™m not going to let my anxiety run my day or stress me out!

Title: A Good Week
Content:
This week has been pretty damn good! No specific reason but I just feel like it has. I finished a book Iâ€™ve been slowly reading over the last month or so and immediately started reading it again. I feel like it has so much good info in it about the process of creating and just really good info about living. Itâ€™s called â€œThe Meaning in the Makingâ€ by Sean Tucker. He also has a youtube channel under his name which I highly recommend as well! I donâ€™t usually re-read books after I finish them or if I do itâ€™s months or years when I get back around to them. Iâ€™ve even started underlining things and Iâ€™m not one to write in the margins but this book makes me want to b/c itâ€™s giving me so much to think about but I donâ€™t want to stop long enough to make a note elsewhere.
Apparently itâ€™s super difficult to get an unsweetened, no cream/milk/whatever iced coffee at starbucksâ€¦this is the second week and I specifically said no sweetener. Even tho Iâ€™ve reversed my diabetes Iâ€™m staying away from added sugar/artificial sweeteners simply b/c I liked sweet stuff soooo much. I donâ€™t want to go back down that rabbit hole. It was easier to overcome sugar back in May when the diagnosis was fresh but now I find myself giving into cravings for things like pizza and bbq..Iâ€™m not overly concerned with the bbq since itâ€™s mainly protein and fat but I donâ€™t want to overdo either. I am concerned with the pizza since I always have a side of â€œloaded friesâ€ with it which has cheese and bacon on it ðŸ˜¬. Iâ€™m concerned with them b/c of the carbs. I donâ€™t think carbs are evil or anything but when I was diagnosed originally I basically landed in a low carb/keto diet. Something I noticed after being on that for a few months is that when I eat a lot of carbs in one sitting I donâ€™t feel well the rest of the day/next day. My joints hurt and I just feel sluggish overall. This is all anecdotal of course but itâ€™s happened a handful of times now. I have still ordered the pizza/fries combo at least weekly but they are getting few and farther between simply b/c of how I feel afterwards. Iâ€™m getting back on the regular exercise track again. Iâ€™ve been stuck at the same weight for over a month now and Iâ€™m still ~30lbs away from my goal weight. One good thing about that is Iâ€™ve been maintaining the same weight, within 1-2lbs, for that amount of time. Iâ€™m pretty proud of myself for that. The last time I lost a lot of weight I wasnâ€™t able to do that b/c I felt hungry *all the time*. Being able to maintain and still eat things I like has been a great exercise.
The weather has been cooling off where I am, finally. I know this is faux fall and weâ€™re bound to have 90*+ days again but the respite from the goddamned heat and humidity has been really nice. I think that is probably why this week has felt like a good week. Itâ€™s so nice waking up to upper 50â€™s and not melting the rest of the day. I feel way more active and motivated to go outside. This year Iâ€™m not looking at the extended forecasts. I realized it was affecting my mood too much and causing me to get angry/depressed at the constant stream of 90+ degree days. The way I felt that first morning of mid-50â€™s confirmed that Iâ€™d made the right choice.
Iâ€™ve book a day trip to another city in my state by train in preparation for my photo trip next year. Itâ€™s ridiculous how much Iâ€™m looking forward to it. It will be a *long* day and I havenâ€™t really done any prep on where to go/what to do when I get to my destination which is definitely unlike me. Iâ€™ll do some research either a few days before or on the train down there. I donâ€™t want to get bogged down in the details so much that my anxiety kicks in and I end up not going. Thatâ€™s happened to me before on a couple of trips. I tried to plan things down to the minute and end up overwhelmed and just saying â€œfuck itâ€ and not going. This will be a trip to mostly test some gear, bags, batteries, packing and what not. Iâ€™m going to do a few more of these day trips to get used to traveling by train and work the bugs out. Hell, I also just want to travel. I really canâ€™t go on â€œbigâ€ trips b/c I canâ€™t afford them right now and Iâ€™m also looking after a family member that would require a bit more planning if I were to go across the country or international. Iâ€™m noticing that I feel better about things when I have something to look forward to. This isnâ€™t really a new revelation to me but it is something Iâ€™ve forgotten about. Photography has been on my mind a lot lately. Iâ€™m still trying to push myself to get out and do more street photography. Itâ€™s really scary to be out in public with a camera these days. My health stuff has been going really well. Iâ€™ve averaged about 1-2lbs loss per week which is right where I want to be. Iâ€™m not going to over do it this go around b/c I donâ€™t want to end up right where I was before and I want to do my best to avoid dealing with any long term issues down the road related to the diabetes.
My September Apple watch goal was to get 67.2 miles in workouts for the month. I completed that goal about midway through the month and have continued to add to that total. Title: I Guess Iâ€™m a Runner Now
Content:
Thanks, I hate it.
lol. I hate running and swore it off a couple of decades ago. Over the last few months Iâ€™ve picked it back up and Iâ€™m amazed at the progress Iâ€™ve made in such a short time. My first run I ran a 15 minute mile, two days I ago I ran a 9m30s mile. Itâ€™s become something I look forward to doing and since Iâ€™ve finally admitted that to myself Iâ€™ve been looking at ways to improve my run even more. Iâ€™m going to start training for a 5k to start out. Iâ€™d like to run under 3o minutes. I ran an impromptu 5k a couple of weeks ago and ran non-stop and ended up at 35 minutes. Looking at training plans for this and Iâ€™m getting the mileage in per week, ~18-20 miles but to improve my time more I need to add in some speed work as well as some longer runs. Right now I donâ€™t do more than 3.5 miles per day and I need to bump that up to get my overall endurance up. The issue Iâ€™m working through right now is my legs feel tired and heavy unless I have a super carby meal the night before. While Iâ€™m technically no longer a type 2 diabetic Iâ€™m leary of upping my carb intake. Iâ€™ve found that I have more joint pain and body aches immediately after eating something carb heavy. My nose also starts running Â and it feels like a mile allergic reaction like when I cut grass the few times of the season. Iâ€™ve emailed my nutritionist to get their advice and guidance on eating for running. Obviously my training volume is going to increase and I absolutely hate that heavy leg feeling and since I canâ€™t really muster more than an 11:30 min mile on those days thatâ€™s not the ideal path to get me to my goal of a sub 30 min 5k.
Iâ€™m excited about having a goal again. I definitely do better with goals but the issue has been over the years I donâ€™t stick with getting to those goals. Iâ€™ve been running consistently now for almost 5 months and on the days I donâ€™t feel like running Iâ€™m able to push myself to do it anyway, which feels good. The cooler temps in the morning have really helped me to look forward to my morning run as well. I struggled over the summer to get a run or even a walk in some days due to the heat/humidity.
Iâ€™ve never considered myself a runner and really still donâ€™t. But the more I do it the more natural it feels and the better I feel during and after the run. Today is a rest day and it also happens to be the coolest morning of the year so far. I find myself wanting to run but I know my body needs the rest so Iâ€™ll just make it a walk today.

Title: Running and Stuff
Content:
Changed some things up with my food intake this week to see if I could shake the heaviness Iâ€™ve had in my legs after 3-4 days of running. I added a sweet potato nightly and was able to bang out 5 days of training this week! My average pace for the week has also dropped by ~2 minutes! Iâ€™ve been working with a nutritionist since my diabetes diagnosis and since thatâ€™s resolved weâ€™ve just kind of rolled over into this running thing. Sheâ€™s been tremendously helpful in dialing things in. The last few months Iâ€™ve been doing 3-4 runs per week and have felt somewhat run down with very heavy legs after each run. I didnâ€™t really feel that this week. Iâ€™ve also added in some foam rolling and I use a racquet ball on the soles of my feet which hurts but also feels amazing.
I really wish that all my experiences with running hadnâ€™t been as a punishment. When I played sports ball and you messed up, â€œtake a lapâ€. When I was in the military and you messed up running was a big part of the â€œcorrective actionâ€. I still say that I hate running and some mornings I doâ€¦But I have really embraced the feeling of getting into a good pace where Iâ€™m being challenged but I can also maintain that pace for what feels like forever. I also love the feeling after Iâ€™m done or the â€œrunnerâ€™s highâ€. I always said I never felt it when I tried running before but I did and I just didnâ€™t allow myself to acknowledge or enjoy that feeling. I do both now. Running has also added a lot of structure to my life. I run in the mornings because I love the feeling of the world waking up while iâ€™m out there. I also *love* running in cold weather. Thereâ€™s this moment just after I finish a run on a cold day, Iâ€™m out of breath and I can see the volume of my breath as it leaves my mouth, thereâ€™s steam coming off me from the sweat, and I all I can see is that steam and all I can hear is my breathing. During that moment I turn off the music or whatever it is I was listening to and I just look around at the world waking up, my breath and the steam coming off me and I smile. It sounds cheesy as hell as I type it out but in that moment I feel so damn good.
Iâ€™ve only posted one time about my running (and my weight loss) on the socials. This is something I am doing for me and just like my photography Iâ€™m not looking for the likes. Thatâ€™s a real shift for me mentally. Pretty sure Iâ€™ve mentioned it before but I was only posting pics and updates that I thought would get the most likes. The more I read about how the backend things work on social media and the way itâ€™s psychologically programmed to keep you on the platform as long as possible the more I want to not be on there. Iâ€™m not going to stop using it altogether b/c I think it can be a good thing but itâ€™s up to me to make it a good and healthy thing for me. Something I didnâ€™t realize until I got an iphone was exactly how much time I spend scrolling. I have set time limits on all social media and use it more a guide than a hard and fast rule. I have a 1 hour limit set for FB, Twitter and Instagram each. I still go over the hour but Iâ€™m way more aware of the time I spend on there now. Iâ€™m also spending more time reading, mostly on my ipad using the kindle app but also dead tree books. The books Iâ€™ve been reading have a lot to do with â€œdigital detoxâ€ and while a few are complete and utter shit a couple have really give me a lot of good ideas and strategies to try.

Title: Making Better Choices, Consistently.
Content:
I read an article about the secret to being â€œgreatâ€. Be good, consistently. It really resonated with me as Iâ€™ve pushed myself to the point of burnout multiple times in my professional life and itâ€™s hard to come back from it. Itâ€™s been easier to not let it happen at all but I still find myself at that point more times than not. This time of year is always hard b/c most of my family has died and while I do have friends that invite me over it just feels like Iâ€™m intruding even though I know thatâ€™s not the case. I typically choose to be alone and then that leads to the depressive episode. Iâ€™m definitely more aware of it this year than I have been in the past so Iâ€™m actively doing things that bring me joy instead of disappearing into that depressive episode.
My mental health is much better this year and I think a large part of that is due to my physical health being better. I went for a run this morning per my schedule and Iâ€™ve noticed that if I donâ€™t run I feel â€¦ off, for lack of a better word. Iâ€™m keeping my running volume to a 5 day on, 3 day off cycle for the structured runs Iâ€™m doing. The last 2 weeks Iâ€™ve thrown in a â€œfree runâ€ on the 2nd day of my 3 day down time. Itâ€™s felt good both weeks and I donâ€™t feel like Iâ€™m doing too much so I think Iâ€™m going to start making it a normal thing. I have to be careful about overtraining and getting injured so before and after each free run Iâ€™m going to take a self assessment to make sure everything still feels good.
Iâ€™m seeing good results from my training program. Iâ€™m using the Maximum Aerobic Function formula (MAF Method) which is subtracting your age from 180 and that gives you your max heart rate for aerobic training. I keep my training within 10 beats of the max. It means Iâ€™m running *a lot* slower than I was previously but Iâ€™m going into my 4th week and Iâ€™m definitely seeing results in my average pace per mile dropping and my heart rate staying within my MAF range. Whatâ€™s that saying â€œslow is smooth and smooth is fastâ€. Iâ€™m doing monthly tests and tracking my daily run times along with some other data which has definitely helped me see the progress Iâ€™m making.

Title: Finally Doing Something!
Content:
Iâ€™ve dabbled in investing over several years but I was never really serious about or serious about planning for my retirement. In caring for the Parental Unit Iâ€™ve realized just how crucial proper planning is. They have some money but itâ€™s likely not going to be enough for skilled care if thatâ€™s ever needed.
I met with a financial advisor this week and I really didnâ€™t know what to expect but it wasnâ€™t what I expected if that makes sense. The whole starting process has a low barrier to entry. Iâ€™m starting out with a brokerage account that has no minimum to start. The fees are just over 1% and annual returns of 7.5-9% based on 5 years meaning some years could be higher and some could be lower. I laid out my vision for retirement and the FA was very frank about it. Itâ€™s possible to meet my goals but Iâ€™m going to have to be focused on contributing consistently and since Iâ€™m single (still :-|) I donâ€™t have very many expenses and I make good money so Iâ€™m able to dump a lot into it per month and still have some money in my pocket. Iâ€™m excited that I may not have to work for the rest to survive. Iâ€™m going to have to be waaaay more disciplined than I have been about saving but the prospect of having a decent retirement is pretty motivating.
I also dropped $500 into a robo-advisor account on Sofi. I set it for a moderately aggressive trading strategy and so far Iâ€™ve made $15 in about two days..Iâ€™ll likely move it to an aggressive strategy as Iâ€™m setting this account up for the long term so Iâ€™m good with some short-term losses for long-term gains. Something has definitely changed in my mindset about money. Iâ€™ve tried to â€œget intoâ€ investing in the past and itâ€™s never really made sense to me. But this time is different. I sat down and wrote out all my expenses and for the first time maybe ever I know where my money is going and that makes me feel better about taking some risks. I donâ€™t want to lose money, obviously, but Iâ€™m ok with some losses to get to where I want to be. Iâ€™m not trading individual stocks since the last time I did that I got pretty obsessive about it and I also donâ€™t want to deal with any kind of capital gains taxes so my investment strategy is for at least a year and then re-evaluate.
The topic of money can be taboo but the more I learn about it and the more it sticks in my head the easier it is to talk about, plan for and deal withâ€¦Maybe thatâ€™s just me, I donâ€™t know.
